subject: Introduce --config-download-verbosity.
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 6926, 'name': 'Bogdan Dobrelya', 'email': 'bdobreli@redhat.com', 'username': 'bogdando'}, {'_account_id': 8833, 'name': 'Rabi Mishra', 'email': 'ramishra@redhat.com', 'username': 'rabi'}, {'_account_id': 18002, 'name': 'John Fulton', 'email': 'fulton@redhat.com', 'username': 'fultonj'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23181, 'name': 'RDO Third Party CI', 'email': 'dmsimard+rdothirdparty@redhat.com', 'username': 'rdothirdparty', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 25877, 'name': 'Luke Short', 'email': 'ekultails@gmail.com', 'username': 'ekultails'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 25877, 'date': '2020-04-14 20:52:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-04-15 08:25:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

please add release notes.

Also, there is more places IIRC that call config download, shall those be adjusted as well?'}, {'account_id': 25877, 'date': '2020-04-15 14:31:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

You are right, there are a few other places config-download is used (external_updates/upgrades). After talking with the team, I am inclined to take another approach to tackle this. We can limit the output to stdout to only be the task names. This will give operators better visibility into what is going on along with allowing the verbosity to be handled by the OpenStack client. We can add some logic similar to this = if 'TASK [' in stdout: print(stdout)"}, {'account_id': 18002, 'date': '2020-04-15 16:05:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Can this be expanded to cover verbosity for more than just config-download?

E.g. 'openstack overcloud deploy' triggers playbooks like:

https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-ansible/blob/master/tripleo_ansible/playbooks/cli-update-params.yaml

When they have issues and I want to debug them how do I increase their verbosity?

And if we add --other-thing-verbosity to address that then do we like that design? Maybe it would be better to have a more global verbosity which increases the verbosity for the many verbosity variables in overcloud_deploy.py?"}, {'account_id': 18002, 'date': '2020-04-15 16:30:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Can this be expanded to cover verbosity for more than just
 > config-download?
 > 
 > E.g. 'openstack overcloud deploy' triggers playbooks like:
 > 
 > https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-ansible/blob/master/tripleo_ansible/playbooks/cli-update-params.yaml
 > 
 > When they have issues and I want to debug them how do I increase
 > their verbosity?
 > 
 > And if we add --other-thing-verbosity to address that then do we
 > like that design? Maybe it would be better to have a more global
 > verbosity which increases the verbosity for the many verbosity
 > variables in overcloud_deploy.py?

Hi Luke,

As per our chat I understand that the ansible-playbook command inherits the verbosity of the OpenStack CLI. So it looks like they work the same way with a differing number of "vees" (-v, -vv, etc) [1]. I assume also then that, --config-download-verbosity doesn't inherit the verbosity of the OpenStack CLI, and that that's why this patch is necessary.

Thanks,
  John

[1] 
[CentOS-8.1 - stack@undercloud tripleo-ansible]$ openstack --help | grep verbosity           
  -v, --verbose         Increase verbosity of output. Can be repeated.                       
/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/barbicanclient/__init__.py:61: UserWarning: The secrets module is moved to barbicanclient/v1 directory, direct import of barbicanclient.secrets will be deprecated. Please import barbicanclient.v1.secrets instead.                                    
  % (name, name, name))
[CentOS-8.1 - stack@undercloud tripleo-ansible]$'}, {'account_id': 18002, 'date': '2020-04-15 16:52:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I wrote:
 > I assume also then that, --config-download-verbosity doesn't
 > inherit the verbosity of the OpenStack CLI, and that that's why
 > this patch is necessary.

I'm wrong again :)

As per the commit message this is aimed at Train and older and for Ussuri and newer config-download also inherits the verbosity."}, {'account_id': 25877, 'date': '2020-04-17 22:34:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Alternative patch posted: https://review.opendev.org/720845'}, {'account_id': 18002, 'date': '2020-04-20 14:31:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Alternative patch posted: https://review.opendev.org/720845

OK, I guess you're waiting for feedback on the alternative before you abandon this patch."}, {'account_id': 25877, 'date': '2020-05-18 17:52:40.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-04-14 20:52:14.000000000', 'message': 'Introduce --config-download-verbosity.

The verbosity of the deployment playbooks to stdout/stderr is now
configurable and output can be disabled entirely. This is useful for
situations where Mistral and Zaqar cannot handle the large amount of
ansible-playbook output. The full Ansible log is still stored in the
ansible.log file.

This inital patch is intended to provide the functionality in Ussuri
so that it may be backported to releases that use Mistral and Zaqar
as part of the deployment.

Change-Id: Ic6dc83d9092d7be799d4f53819e653bef46dccea
Closes-Bug: #1872823
Signed-off-by: Luke Short <ekultails@gmail.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Introduce --config-download-verbosity.

The verbosity of the deployment playbooks to stdout/stderr is now
configurable and output can be disabled entirely. This is useful for
situations where Mistral and Zaqar cannot handle the large amount of
ansible-playbook output. The full Ansible log is still stored in the
ansible.log file.

This inital patch is intended to provide the functionality in Ussuri
so that it may be backported to releases that use Mistral and Zaqar
as part of the deployment.

Change-Id: Ic6dc83d9092d7be799d4f53819e653bef46dccea
Closes-Bug: #1872823
Signed-off-by: Luke Short <ekultails@gmail.com>

[{'created': '2020-05-17 20:28:38.000000000', 'message': 'Fix UEFI boot support

UEFI booting support was removed on Debian/Ubuntu was broken by the
removal of ovmf and qemu-efi package installs during a package list
cleanup[1].

It looks like suse/redhat did not reecive the same cleanup effects,
as the UEFI bootloader packages are still installed there, so no
fix is needed on those OS families.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/662585/

Change-Id: I8ce72e4a0c754a745b1abf42030e41d6084f1361
'}]
commit_message:
Fix UEFI boot support

UEFI booting support was removed on Debian/Ubuntu was broken by the
removal of ovmf and qemu-efi package installs during a package list
cleanup[1].

It looks like suse/redhat did not reecive the same cleanup effects,
as the UEFI bootloader packages are still installed there, so no
fix is needed on those OS families.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/662585/

Change-Id: I8ce72e4a0c754a745b1abf42030e41d6084f1361

I am not familiar with plugins in Kolla but adding the OVN provider driver to the base does not look optimal. Octavia provider drivers are required in the octavia-api service. Some provider drivers may also have to be installed in the octavia-driver-agent service which, at least in TripleO, uses the octavia-api container image.'}, {'account_id': 22629, 'date': '2020-05-14 17:36:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 22629, 'date': '2020-05-14 17:37:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

> I am not familiar with plugins in Kolla but adding the OVN provider
 > driver to the base does not look optimal. Octavia provider drivers
 > are required in the octavia-api service. Some provider drivers may
 > also have to be installed in the octavia-driver-agent service
 > which, at least in TripleO, uses the octavia-api container image.

Thanks Carlos, I was under the impression octavia-worker also needs that, but I'm not very familiar with Octavia."}, {'account_id': 6469, 'date': '2020-05-14 17:41:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

All good, thank you for considering my feedback and for promptly update the patch! Just a small comment on a line duplicate, otherwise LGTM.

The Worker, Health Manager and Housekeeping are services of the amphora driver. I understand the confusion as until Rocky there was no providers support so it was only the amphora driver (before simply called "octavia" provider).'}, {'account_id': 22629, 'date': '2020-05-15 06:32:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 14.'}, {'account_id': 22629, 'date': '2020-05-15 06:35:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 15.'}, {'account_id': 22629, 'date': '2020-05-15 09:12:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15: Review-Priority+1'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2020-05-15 15:24:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15: Code-Review-1

commit_message:
octavia: Add ovn-octavia-driver

During this cycle Neutron team merged networking-ovn code to Neutron.
As a consequence of it "OVN Octavia provider" project has been created.
Before it the driver was placed in networking-ovn tree.

Change-Id: I0dcd34b5e2c096557f0485aaec83d344e5cb01bb

commit_message:
Cleanup deprecated iteritems of dict

To fix the issue because of using deprecated method in python3, replace
iteritems() with items().

Change-Id: If3136a5ba471d2cd7ea9420b599567a2fa532cad
Partial-Bug: 1872120
